ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

NATIONAL SERVICE
REGISTRANTS NOT CALLED UP
(Issue of exemption letters to find employment)


    1. Tuan Haji Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi asked the Minister of Defence if exemption permits can be issued to

Column: 280

persons who have already registered for national service and have undergone the necessary test but have not yet been called up, so as to enable them to find employment.

Letters of exemption from full-time national service are given to persons who are not enlisted within one year after they are due for national service call-up. These letters are intended to enable them to find employment.

TELEX SERVICE IN SINGAPORE
(Capacity and efficiency)


    2. Mr P. Selvadurai asked the Minister for Communications if he is satisfied with the capacity and efficiency of the Telex service in Singapore.

    The Minister for Communications (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Speaker, Sir, because the demand for Telex service in Singapore has grown at an accelerated rate in recent years (the growth rate for the first half of 1971 is 60 per cent on that of the same period for 1970) and the fact that suppliers for teleprinter have not been able to honour delivery dates last year, I regret to state that the Telex service at present is not as satisfactory as we would want it to be.

    However, we have taken the following steps to improve the situation:

    Firstly, in the middle of last year, an order was made for 262 Telex machines, and again in January this

Column: 281

year, another order for 503 Telex machines was made, thus making a total of 765 machines on order at a cost of $2.6 million. As the present number of applicants for Telex machines who are on the waiting list is 249, subject to the above suppliers meeting their delivery dates, we should be able to satisfy the present demand for Telex machines in full by the middle of next year.

    Secondly, 400 lines of the 1,200-line National Automatic Telex Exchange, costing $1.96 million, will be commissioned into operation this month (October). The full capacity of this exchange will be realised by the middle of next year.

    Thirdly, a 150-channel automatic International Telex Exchange has been ordered at a cost of $640,000, and should be operational early in 1973.

PORT OF SINGAPORE AUTHORITY
(Introduction of four-shift system)


    3. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Communications whether the Port of Singapore Authority is considering the introduction of a 4-shift system for port workers, and whether there will be sufficient workers to man the shifts.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, as the present three-shift system for dock workers in the Port of Singapore Authority would appear to be adequate to meet the requirements of the shipping community, there is therefore no intention on the part of P.S.A. to introduce a four-shift system.

INSURANCE COVERAGE FOR MOTOR VEHICLES


    4. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Communications if he will take the necessary measures to ensure that every person applying for a motor vehicle licence has a valid policy of insurance to cover the vehicle for the full period for which the licence is to be taken out.

Column: 282



    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to thank the Member for Kallang for highlighting a problem which the Registrar of Vehicles has been faced with for some time.

    It is true that under existing legislation, a vehicle owner need produce only an insurance policy valid on the day that he applies to renew the annual road licence. In some cases, the insurance policy may expire or becomes invalid before the road licence expires.

    My Ministry proposes to introduce legislation soon to ensure that vehicle owners do take out insurance policies which will be valid for the full period for which a road licence is applied for. It has not been possible to do this earlier because of the immense problem of record keeping, which will soon be resolved when the Registry of Vehicles computerises its records by early 1972.

CRASH PROGRAMME FOR TRAINING RELIEF TEACHERS


    5. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Education why there is still a large number of relief teachers, who are untrained, and if his Ministry is planning a crash programme to train such teachers.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, as at 1st October, 1971, there were 1,115 relief teachers, of whom 246 were trained teachers. It is expected that by May 1972, when the next batch of teachers graduate from the Teachers' Training College, another 845 trained teachers will be added to the pool of relief teachers, replacing those who are untrained. Under these circumstances, Mr Speaker, Sir, it is unnecessary to conduct a crash programme to train relief teachers.

MEDICAL BENEFITS FOR FAMILIES OF
GOVERNMENT AIDED SCHOOL STAFF


    6. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister for Education, in view of the taking over of two British hospitals, recently, if the Government will consider

Column: 283

extending medical benefits to the families of the staff serving in Government-aided schools.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, when the medical benefits accorded to Government servants were extended to aided school staff with effect from 1st September, 1970, it was announced that the same medical benefits would be extended to their families when sufficient ward accommodation became available. Although the Ministry of Health has taken over Alexandra Hospital and Sembawang Hospital, the necessary medical facilities, in particular ward accommodation, are not immediately available to give a reasonably satisfactory service to the persons concerned.

    Alexandra Hospital was taken over with effect from 10th September, 1971, and is not fully operational as yet. The present service is limited to medical and paediatric cases only. The Surgical, Orthopaedic, and Obstetrical Units have not yet been established. The paying class wards which will be required to accommodate members of the families of aided school staff are also not ready yet. The other services will be provided by stages as the relevant equipment is purchased and installed, and structural alterations to the building are carried out.

    Sembawang Hospital is a small hospital with 68 "C" class beds. It has been set aside for the use of convalescent cases only.

    In view of the above, Sir, it is not possible at the moment to extend the medical benefits enjoyed by aided school staff to families. However, when Alexandra Hospital becomes fully operational, i.e., when it is able to provide the full range of services and the structural alterations to the building are completed, this matter will again be considered.

    Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): Sir, if at the moment the medical authorities cannot provide ward facilities for members of families of those teachers who are employed in the aided schools,

Column: 284

can they at least provide them with outpatient services? And if they cannot, why not?

    Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, I believe it would be more profitable if the Member directed his question to the Minister for Health.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Chua, would you like to answer that supplementary question?

    The Minister for Health (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Sir, I think that matter does not fall within my portfolio, because if it is decided that we provide' them with outpatient services, then we will provide them.

    Mr N. Govindasamy: May I have your guidance, Mr Speaker, Sir? To whom shall I direct my question if the Minister for Health thinks that it does, not concern him?

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir,. I have said that as soon as facilities, are available and since a promise has been made, we will extend medical benefits to the families of aided school teachers. But whether the hospitals can undertake operations on members of their families -

    Mr Speaker: Outpatient services.

    Mr Lim Kim San: I am sorry. I thought it was operations. Sir, there are outpatient facilities available all over Singapore, and there is no reason why they cannot go to the hospitals for outpatient treatment.

    Mr N. Govindasamy: Sir, for out-patient treatment they have got to pay at the moment. The point raised was, this: as Government servants are accorded free outpatient treatment as well as ward treatment, why should not suck benefits be extended to the families of aided school teachers?

    Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, applications can be made to the Ministry of Finance for a waiver of these fees, if necessary.

DRUG ADDICTION AMONG STUDENTS
(Particulars)


    7. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Education (a) how serious is drug addiction among students (secondary and tertiary) and how many students were found to be involved between 1st January, 1971, and the latest convenient date; and (b) how have they been dealt with by the authorities concerned.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no known case of drug addiction among secondary school students. However, the number of secondary school students found to have experimented in the taking of drugs is on the increase. Between 1st January and 8th October of this year, 39 such cases involving 10 girls and 29 boys have come to light. The tertiary institutions have not reported any case of drug addiction or drug taking.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, whenever a student is suspected of having taken drugs, his or her parents are immediately consulted so that a closer care can be taken of the potential addict and the necessary advice and medical help given. Some cases are referred to the Child Guidance `Clinic of the Ministry of Health where trained persons can counsel the students and give therapeutic help if necessary. But the main object must be to track down the pusher of drugs.

SPORTS IN SINGAPORE
(Measures to raise standard)


    8. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Social Affairs what measures are being taken to raise the standard of sports in Singapore to international standards.

    The Minister for Social Affairs (Inche Othman Bin Wok): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Singapore National Olympics Council has a sub-committee working on several three-year "training and `coaching" plans submitted by its affiliates. All sports organisations have been advised to place special emphasis

Column: 286

on the progressive training of their particular branch of sports in order to raise their proficiency to international standards. At the moment, there is already a scheme for Badminton promotion involving seven different training centres based on the three-year programme with the aim of creating a substantial corps of Badminton players of a reasonably high standard to be considered for the national team. These centres provide training for the youths in schools as well as those who are members of sports organisations and the community centres.

    The National Sports Promotion Board is represented on the sub-committee responsible for "training and coaching" and is giving every assistance to ensure the success of the plans put up by the various sports controlling bodies.

    Hand in hand with the training given to participants of the various sports, this sub-committee is also planning a scheme to train coaches as well. The training envisaged for these coaches will be conducted both locally and overseas.

    In addition to the training schemes which have been mentioned, the various sports organisations are encouraged to hold regular competitions locally and to send their best talents to compete in regional and international sports meets to enable them to gain international experience.

    I feel confident, Sir, that the standards of sports in Singapore will reach new heights in the near future.

Column: 286

"FAKIR MISKIN" AND "FITRAH"
(Particulars)


    9. Inche Rahmat Bin Kenap Al-Haj asked the Minister for Social Affairs (a) who are the people classified as "Fakir Miskin" who are entitled to receive assistance from the "Fitrah" collected by the Majlis Ugama Islam; (b) how many Muslims are given this assistance and of these how many are also receiving Social Welfare assistance; and (c) what action has been taken against Muslims who have not paid their "Fitrah" last year and how many are involved.

Column: 287



    Inche Othman Bin Wok: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Geylang Serai is aware that the exercise of Fitrah is a requirement in the tenets of Islam and is now a common feature in many countries with Muslims. The disbursement of Fitrah is governed by Muslim law which specifically provides for the definition and qualification for the Fakirs and the Miskins who generally may be said to be the deserving and the very deserving of the Muslims for collective financial assistance by Muslims as a whole towards the end of Ramadan, the month of the fast. The basis for this in Singapore is determined by the Majlis Ugama Islam who are also responsible for the collection and distribution of Fitrah. The Majlis Ugama Islam applies a means test on applicants who claim to be either Fakir or Miskin. They are registered yearly with details of their incomes before payments are made.

    In 1970, $73,912 was paid out from the Fitrah Account to 18,478 Muslims classified as Fakir or Miskin. They were each given $4.00. It is not possible to ascertain how many of the 18,478 Muslims who are classified in this category are also on public assistance.

    In 1970 also, a total of 649 Muslims were reported by the Amils as having defaulted in the payment of Fitrah. Letters were sent out requesting them to call for an interview. Investigation revealed that in most cases failure to pay was due to poor financial circumstances. A few claimed preference to pay during the last three days of Ramadan but fell ill and were accordingly unable to comply with the law; some removed to new addresses and inquiries with the National Registration Office confirmed they had not reported changes of addresses. Yet a few others turned up later to make late payments. The figure of 649 represents only a small fraction of defaulters the Majlis Ugama Islam have managed to act on. However, the Majlis are now trying to compile a register of Muslims in Singapore, the completion of which would assist them greatly in tracking those who have failed to make Fitrah payments.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD
(Allocation of flats for rental or purchase)


    11. Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he will ascertain from the Housing and Development Board (a) how many applicants, who have registered to rent (i) 2-room flats; and (ii) 3-room fiats, have been on the waiting list for (1) 2 years or more; and (ii) less than 2 years, but had not given any undertaking of their willingness to wait indefinitely for allocation; and (b) whether priority in the allocation of flats will be given to such applicants if they have registered to purchase the flats.

    Mr Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, as at the 31st August, 1971, 7,032 applicants had registered for 2-room flats. Of these applicants, 1,976 have registered for more than two years and 5,056 for less, out of which 3,287 have not indicated their willingness to wait indefinitely.

    As at 31st August, 1971, 3,312 applicants had registered for 3-room flats. Of these, 1,295 have registered for more than two years and 2,017 for less, out of which 1,751 have not indicated their willingness to wait indefinitely.

Column: 289



    The Housing and Development Board maintains two sets of registers, one for rental and one for the purchase of flats. No priority is given to applicants on the rental register who desire to switch over to the purchase register.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD
(Sale of terrace houses and flats)


    12. Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon asked the Minster for Law and National Development if he will ascertain from the Housing and Development Board whether it is proposed to sell (i) 2-storey terrace houses at Jalan Membina; and (ii) flats at Lim Liak Street/Kim Cheng Street/Kim Pong Road.

However, if the majority of the tenants indicate that they wish to purchase these terrace houses or flats, the Housing and Development Board will certainly consider the proposal.

REFORMATIVE MEASURES FOR
GANJA AND MX PILL USERS


    15. Inche Rahmat Bin Kenap Al-Haj asked the Minister for Health what reformative measures are being taken in respect of ganja and MX pill users.

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no uniform opinion on the reformative measures for ganja and MX pill users.

    These two drugs are not as dangerous as opium, morphine, heroin and other hard drugs where users find themselves quickly and easily addicted. The effects .are physically and mentally destructive.

    Any drug, including ganja and MX pills, is bad. Although these two drugs may not create the same physical dependence as morphine or heroin, they create a psychological dependence. This occurs in persons with inadequate personalities, making them excessively reliant on other people, or dependent on the drugs. The taking of ganja and MX pills can lead to the taking of the more dangerous drugs.

    Ganja smoking has a longer history. Not much medical research has gone into it. Those that have come to our attention have been those who have been arrested or are in custody. For those persons in prison, an attempt is made to get them to rid themselves of the need to fall back on smoking ganja. So far we have admitted 17 ganja addicts to the St. John's Island treatment centre. For the ganja addict, treatment is relatively simple. At St. John's Island they are encouraged to participate in healthy activities and to convince them that they need no ganja. `They participate in gardening, tailoring, carpentry and fish rearing.

    The problem of MX pill takers is relatively new. Very little is known about the long-term effects of this drug. MX is the pharmaceutical preparation under the trade name of "Mandrax" which is a preparation of methaqualone, which is a mild hypnotic combined with an antihistamine. It is curious why it has been pushed by drug pedals, and

Column: 292

why it has been so readily accepted by some persons. It is not a "mind bending" drug, such as L.S.D., nor a stimulant, such as the pep pills. It may be taken out of curiosity or because it has got a potentiating effect not known pharmaceutically. Whatever the reason, its use without a doctor's control causes concern.

    The few cases that have been brought to the attention of the clinicians have been cases of over-dosage. The treatment has been to wash out the stomach. About a dozen patients are known to have been treated in this way.

    Since prevention is better than cure, the Medical Department has been disseminating knowledge on the dangers of these drugs to various groups of people who deal with young persons. Lectures were given this year to the Samaritans, psychiatric nurses, customs officers, school health doctors and officers of the Singapore Command and Staff College, and to school students and other groups of younger people.

    A special clinic has been formed in one of the Medical departments in the Outram Road General Hospital where ganja smokers and persons on MX pills and others are treated and counselled. The follow-up is undertaken by doctors, almoners and other voluntary staff. Arrangements have also been made with the Chinese Y.M.C.A, to undertake the rehabilitation of some of these persons through group activities.

FUND FOR PAYMENT OF DAMAGES TO ACCIDENT VICTIMS


    17. Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon asked the Minister for Finance, as there have been cases of accident victims who, though awarded sums of money as damages by the Courts, were unable to get the money for various reasons, for example, there was no valid insurance cover and the defendant was not able to pay the damages awarded, if he will consider setting up a fund, to be subscribed to by insurance companies, from which payments of damages can be made in such cases.

    The Minister of State for Finance (Mr Tang See Chim) (for the Minister for Finance): No, Mr Speaker, Sir. I am aware that in certain countries insurance companies do operate a fund, under the aegis of a Motor Insurers' Bureau, for the purpose of compensating victims of accidents in which the motor vehicle concerned was being used without proper insurance cover. We cannot set up a similar fund without raising the rates of premium on motor insurance, which would adversely affect the motoring public. My Ministry, however, is considering whether the difficulties raised in the Member's question can be overcome without the disadvantage of higher premiums on motor insurance.

TEN PER CENT IMPORT SURCHARGE BY U.S. GOVERNMENT
(Effect on Singapore's industries)


    18. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Finance what significant impact has been caused to Singapore's industries by the imposition of the 10 per cent import surcharge by the United States Government.

    Mr Tang See Chim (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, first I should perhaps explain briefly the nature of the 10 per cent import surcharge and the pattern of our trade with the United States.

Column: 294



    The 10 per cent import surcharge' was imposed by the American Government on 16th August, 1971, as a temporary supplemental duty and as one of the measures to cope with their balance of payment difficulties. It is applicable to goods entering the United States which are already subject to import duty.
